questions.text: Which is the only nucleotide (not nucleoside) analogue that is commonly used in HIV ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tenofovir

Highyeild:

Tenofovir is the only nucleotide approved for HIV treatment This is the only nucleotide (not nucleoside) analogue that is a commonly used anti-HIV drug. It is also active against HBV. Tenofovir was initially used only in previously treated patients, but because of its good tolerability profile, it is now being included in first-line regimens as well. Tenofovir-containing regimens have been found at least as effective and less toxic as other first-line regimens. It is included in the preferred 1st line WHO regimen for adults and adolescents. Renal toxicity is to be watched.

questions.text: Rilpivirine is approved for HIV 1 infection in children >12 years and adults belong to which group ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NNRTI

Highyeild:

Types of HIV Two species of HIV infect humans: 1. HIV-1 (identified in 1983) More virulent, relatively easy to transmit Majority of HIV infections globally 3 types of HIV-1: (based on alterations in env gene) 2. HIV-2 (identified in 1986) Less transmittable Largely confined to West Africa NNRTIs Nevirapine Efavirenz Delavirdine Etravirine Rilpivirine Rilpivirine is a diaryl pyrimidine NNRTI with potent activity against HIV-1. The drug should be used only in combination with other effective agents and should not be added as the sole new agent to a failing regimen. Rilpivirine has the best side-effect profile of available NNRTIs and has few or no CNS side effects compared to efavirenz. Rilpivirine retains efficacy against many HIV strains that are resistant to efavirenz and other earlier NNRTIs.

questions.text: A HIV patient is on indinavir, zidovudine, lamivudine and ketoconazole. He developed breast hypertrophy, nephrolithiasis, hyperlipidemia and central obesity. Which of the following drug is responsible for the above adverse drug reaction ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Indinavir

Highyeild:

Indinavir is a protease inhibitor protease inhibitors cause metabolic syndromes like hyperlipidemia and central obesity Indinavir causes nephrolithiasis in about 3% of patients patients are recommended to drink plenty of water while using it The most prominent adverse effects of PIs are gastrointestinal intolerance, asthenia, headache, dizziness, limb and facial tingling, numbness and rashes. Of particular concern are lipodystrophy (abdominal obesity, buffalo hump with wasting of limbs and face), and dyslipidaemia (raised triglycerides and cholesterol) which may necessitate restriction of lipids in diet. Insulin resistance occurs and diabetes may be exacerbated. Indinavir crystalises in urine and increases the risk of urinary calculi.

Applied to the skin it is used for fungal skin infections such as tinea, cutaneous candidiasis, and pityriasis versicolor. Option: D . Zidovudine also known as azidothymidine (AZT), is an antiretroviral medication used to prevent and treat HIV/AIDS. It is generally recommended for use in combination with other antiretrovirals. questions.text: Among the following options, the Mechanism of action of oseltamivir is :

options.label: C
options.text: Viral M2 ion channel protein inhibition

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neuraminidase inhibitor

Highyeild:

Oseltamivir is a Neuraminidase inhibitor, used in prophylaxis and treatment of influenza A, B, H1N1, H5N9 Oseltamivir acts by inhibiting the influenza virus neuraminidase enzyme which is needed for the release of progeny virions from the infected cell. The Spread of the virus in the body is thus checked. Resistance can develop by mutation of the viral neuraminidase enzyme. In many areas oseltamivir-resistant influenza A (seasonal influenza) and H5N1 have been encountered, though swine flu (H1N1) is still mostly sensitive. Some oseltamivir-resistant strains remain susceptible to zanamivir.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B . Remdesivir is an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibitor. Option: C . Antiinfluenza drug amantadine act on viral m2 protein Option: D. Atazanavir and darunavir are fusion inhibitors.

questions.text: Which of the following neuraminidase inhibitor given by nasal route?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zanamivir Oseltamivir is given by oral route zanamivir is given by nasal route peramivir given by parenteral route(IV)

Highyeild:

Zanamivir Another influenza A (including amantadine-resistant, H1N1, H5N1 strains) and influenza B virus neuraminidase inhibitor that is administered by inhalation as a powder due to very low oral bioavailability. The small amount that is absorbed after inhalation is excreted by the kidney with a t½ of 2–5 hours. The mechanism of action, clinical utility and efficacy of zanamivir are similar to that of oseltamivir. Some strains resistant to oseltamivir remain sensitive to zanamivir. Therefore, it should be reserved for oseltamivir-resistant cases, or when the latter cannot be given, or for severely immunocompromised patients. Prophylactic use may be made for 7–10 days in household contacts. Dose: 10 mg through a breath-actuated inhaler or rotacaps, BD × 5 days for treatment, and OD for prophylaxis

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Oseltamivir is an antiviral medication used to treat and prevent influenza A and influenza B, viruses that cause the flu. Many medical organizations recommend it for people who have complications or are at high risk of complications within 48 hours of first symptoms. Option: C. Peramivir is an antiviral drug developed by BioCryst Pharmaceuticals for the treatment of influenza. Peramivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor, acting as a transition-state analogue inhibitor of influenza neuraminidase and thereby preventing new viruses from emerging

questions.text: Which of the following drug doesn’t require activation by phosphorylation ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Foscarnet

Highyeild:

Foscarnet Inhibits herpesvirus DNA polymerase, RNA polymerase, and HIV reverse transcriptase directly without requiring activation by phosphorylation. Blocks the pyrophosphate binding site of these enzymes and inhibits cleavage of pyrophosphate from deoxynucleotide triphosphates DOC for resistant CMV retinitis, CMV colitis, CMV esophagitis DOC for acyclovir-resistant HSV infection and acyclovir-resistant VZV infection Trifluridine Pyrimidine nucleoside that inhibits viral DNA synthesis in HSV-1, HSV-2, CMV, vaccinia, and some adenoviruses. Phosphorylated intra- cellularly by host cell enzymes, and then competes with thymidine triphosphate for incorporation by the viral DNA polymerase Ganciclovir Acyclic guanosine analogue Requires activation by triphosphorylation before inhibiting the viral DNA polymerase Cidofovir cytosine nucleotide analogue In contrast to ganciclovir, phosphorylation of cidofovir to the active diphosphate is independent of viral enzymes
